parameter 1: Kino International released a video with a music soundtrack by Alexander Rannie and Brian Benison (music © 1991). Running time is 101 minutes.
parameter 2: Kino International released a video with a music soundtrack by Alexander Rannie and Brian Benison (music © 1991). Running time is 101 minutes.
parameter 3: The original theatrical release had 'György Ligeti' (qv)'s "Atmospheres" set to a black screen for roughly 8 to 10 minutes before the movie began, and 'Johann Strauß' (qv)'s "The Blue Danube" long after the end credits set to a black screen. This overture and exit music survived the premiere edits mentioned above. For a long while, revivals and all television and cable broadcasts would cut both, starting directly at the beginning of the credits and ending immediately after the end credits, but current revivals in such places as the Film Forum in New York City and cable channels such as the Sundance Channel, Bravo, the Independent Channel, and PBS have been restoring the pre- and post-movie music.
parameter 4: On the DVD release, the film can be watched in "Bad English". Instead of the dubbed dialogue, you hear all the original location dialogue (see trivia).
parameter 5: Originally by Mark Smith <msmith@osi.co.uk>, edited and emended.
Most current video versions contain the 139-minute general release version plus the original overture, entr'acte, and exit music from the roadshow version.
parameter 6: In 2007 a computer-colorized version was released. The 50th Anniversary Edition on DVD and Blu-ray includes both the original black & white and colorized versions.
parameter 7: German theatrical version was edited (rat torture scene) for a more commercial "Not under 12" rating.
parameter 8: Many local TV stations delete the scene in which the Ymir kills an elephant from a zoo, claiming the scene is a needless depiction of cruelty to animals.
parameter 9: There is an international version, with English subtitles.
parameter 10: Some versions have title cards on-screen during the Overture and Entr'acte sections, while other versions omit these titles and simply play the music over a black screen.
parameter 11: Most current video versions contain the 139-minute general release version plus the original overture, entr'acte, and exit music from the roadshow version.
parameter 12: This film was also released in a "flat" version.  This was optically derived from the anamorphic negative.  This was for release in small cities where there were no theatres yet equiped for Cinemascope.
parameter 13: Most current video versions contain the 139-minute general release version plus the original overture, entr'acte, and exit music from the roadshow version.
parameter 14: Kino International released a video with a music soundtrack by Alexander Rannie and Brian Benison (music © 1991). Running time is 101 minutes.
parameter 15: The film originally premiered at 160 minutes. After the premiere, director 'Stanley Kubrick' (qv) removed about 19 minutes' worth of scenes and made a few changes: - Some shots from the "Dawn of Man" sequence were removed and a new scene was inserted where an ape pauses with the bone it is about to use as a tool. The new scene was a low-angle shot of the monolith, done in order to portray and clarify the connection between the man-ape using the tool and the monolith. - Some shots of Frank Poole jogging in the centrifuge were removed. - An entire sequence of several shots in which Dave Bowman searches for the replacement antenna part in storage was removed. - A scene where HAL severs radio communication between the "Discovery" and Poole's pod before killing him was removed. This scene explains a line that stayed in the film in which Bowman addresses HAL on the subject. - Some shots of Poole's space walk before he is killed were removed.
parameter 16: A laserdisc issue deletes the "Dental Hygiene Dilemma/quasi-Donald Duck on acid" animation sequence.

parameter 21: There was an alternate ending that was featured on the DVD. After Captain Michaels announces that they are heading to the Cape of Good Hope, he tells Dr. Helmsley that he has a phone call waiting for him. Dr. Helmsley discovers that his dad Harry is still alive. Harry tells his son that he, Tony (whose arm is in a sling) and some of the passengers and crew survived the mega-tsunami that struck the Genesis. Captain Michaels states that they should have a visual on the ocean-liner shortly. After Kate thanks Laura for taking care of Lily, Laura tells Jackson that she liked his book. Lily then announces that she sees an island. The Arks arrive at the shipwrecked Genesis and the survivors on the beach.

parameter 27: The original theatrical release had 'György Ligeti' (qv)'s "Atmospheres" set to a black screen for roughly 8 to 10 minutes before the movie began, and 'Johann Strauß' (qv)'s "The Blue Danube" long after the end credits set to a black screen. For a long while, revivals and all television and cable broadcasts would cut both, starting directly at the beginning of the credits and ending immediately after the end credits, but current revivals in such places as the Film Forum in New York City and cable channels such as the Sundance Channel, Bravo, the Independent Channel, and PBS have been restoring the pre- and post-movie music.
parameter 28: Many local TV stations delete the scene in which the Ymir kills an elephant from a zoo, claiming the scene is a needless depiction of cruelty to animals.
parameter 29: The DVD version from MGM omits a few seconds of dialogue from the scene in which Dave is attempting to re-enter the Discovery through the pod bay doors. Dave asks several times, "Do you read me, HAL?" In the original release, HAL answers, "Affirmative, Dave. I read you." In the DVD version, HAL only answers "Affirmative, Dave," although the English subtitles still contains "I read you." The DVD release from Warner Bros. corrects this and HAL's full line of dialogue is heard.
parameter 30: There is an international version, with English subtitles.
